The list is strong and generally stays within scope, but there are some minor requirement mismatches: (1) It includes a dedicated lesson on the TCP three-way handshake and related flag details; while TCP is in-scope, this level of handshake mechanics may overlap the neighboring "HTTPS and TLS" chapter’s handshake focus (not TLS itself, but the chapter asked to avoid dedicated TLS handshake lessons; TCP handshake is still arguably OK but borderline). (2) A few lessons are slightly multi-concept in practice (e.g., "Sources of Latency" covers distance, hops, speed-of-light, and queuing; "Slow Connections" bundles several causes). (3) The chapter description mentions "routing" broadly but there’s no explicit lesson on "Routing vs switching"; switching is introduced, but the boundary concept isn’t explicitly isolated. These are minor because the overall set remains usable and mostly compliant.

Opportunities to improve completeness/granularity while staying in-scope: (1) Add IPv6 as its own micro-set (IPv6 address basics, shorthand notation, /64 mental model, dual-stack troubleshooting) since modern web networking often requires it and it fits "IP addressing". (2) Split a few bundled failure/latency lessons into narrower ones (propagation delay vs queuing delay; congestion vs bufferbloat; "slow but not down" into distinct symptoms). (3) Add a couple more concrete failure modes explicitly: misconfigured subnet mask, duplicate IP, gateway ARP failure, MTU mismatch on VPN specifically, ICMP blocked as a failure amplifier (separate from general ICMP role). (4) Add one or two explicit mental-model lessons mapping symptoms to OSI layers (e.g., "Ping works, TCP fails" as a generic pattern) to align with "practical mental models" goal. These are improvements, not blockers.

(2) Several lesson titles bundle multiple distinct concepts with "e" in a way that likely exceeds the single-concept requirement, e.g., "Arquitetura como decisões estruturais que guiam desenvolvimento e operação, mantendo espaço para mudança frequente" (title: "Arquitetura em ambientes ágeis" but description combines multiple ideas), "Autonomia com coerência" (two concepts), "Fronteiras e ownership" (two concepts), "Lock-in por tecnologia" description mentions multiple types (technology, data, operation) though separate lessons exist later—this one is internally inconsistent. These issues materially reduce compliance with the single-concept and scope constraints.

Minor issues: (1) Some lessons are slightly abstract and may be hard to teach in 2–3 minutes without further splitting, e.g., "Princípios arquiteturais explícitos", "Padrões de qualidade arquitetural", "Pragmatismo arquitetural", "Alavancas arquiteturais"—each could hide multiple sub-concepts. steps.conclusion: Major errors found: (1) Several lesson titles include the forbidden word “as” in a way that often indicates multi-concept framing, but the critical requirement only explicitly bans “learn/understand/explore/introduction/basics,” so this is not itself a violation. However, there are concrete scope violations with neighboring chapters: multiple lessons are primarily about urbanization/urban reform dynamics rather than health mechanisms (e.g., “Urban sanitation infrastructure,” “Urban reform as a health risk,” “Urban growth as health pressure”). While sanitation is in-scope, these drift toward urban policy/infrastructure as the main subject rather than health systems/epidemiology; at least “Urban sanitation infrastructure” substantially overlaps the neighboring chapter explicitly covering sanitation. (2) Some lessons are too broad to fit the single-concept / 10-tweets constraint, e.g., “Health policy under dictatorship,” “HIV/AIDS policy model,” “COVID-19 governance conflicts,” “Medicines policy,” each bundles multiple mechanisms and subtopics that would require further splitting; this is a core requirement breach because granularity is central. (3) Coverage is not consistently separated as requested: public health policy vs biomedical politics are mixed in places (e.g., “Vaccination as state policy,” “Biomedical authority in politics,” “Protocols as political instruments” are ok, but other policy lessons embed biomedical politics and vice versa). These issues materially reduce compliance with the prompt’s most important constraints (single-concept focus and neighboring-chapter boundaries).

Minor errors found: (1) Some titles use potentially fluffy/abstract phrasing rather than concrete single concepts (e.g., “Therapeutic revolutions,” “Sanitation as modernization ideology”). (2) A few descriptions contain multiple examples/clauses that may hide more than one concept (e.g., “Imperial-era public health institutions” lists quarantine, ports, hospitals, charity care). (3) Periodization is uneven: early 20th-century epidemics beyond smallpox/yellow fever (e.g., 1918 influenza) are missing, and some disease-specific threads (cholera) are absent; this is a completeness/granularity gap but not necessarily fatal given the broad time span. (4) Some lessons lean toward sociology/politics (e.g., “Media framing of epidemics”) which may be in-scope but could be tighter to “health communication during epidemics” as one mechanism.

Potential improvements: (1) Split broad items into tighter micro-lessons (e.g., dictatorship-era health: financing, infrastructure expansion, surveillance, inequality; HIV/AIDS: activism, prevention, ART universalization, pharma production; COVID-19: ICU collapse, oxygen logistics, vaccine procurement, federalism disputes). (2) Reframe or remove lessons that substantially teach neighboring-chapter topics; keep sanitation/infrastructure only when framed as a health mechanism (waterborne transmission, vector habitat, outbreak correlation) rather than urban policy. (3) Add missing major epidemics and campaign nodes explicitly mentioned/implicit in scope: 1918 influenza in Brazil, yellow fever specifics, cholera waves, polio vaccination campaigns, meningitis outbreak under dictatorship, etc., each as its own single-concept lesson. (4) Enforce the expectation to separate “health systems” vs “sanitation campaigns” vs “epidemics” by creating distinct sub-sequences per period (Empire, First Republic, Vargas, dictatorship, redemocratization/SUS, 21st century) with parallel tracks.

Documenting empirical patterns/observations of X within this chapter's context is NOT the same as teaching X's theory (e.g., documenting consumption's cyclical behavior is a business cycle fact, not consumption theory)
  - When a lesson's title mentions a neighboring topic, read the description to determine focus. A lesson titled "Cortiços as disease ecologies" focused on disease transmission is health content, not urbanization content

  Things to check:
  - Is each lesson too broad? If so, it should be broken down further
  - Can each concept be explained in 10 short tweets or less? If not, it should be broken down
  - Does each lesson focus on a single specific concept? If not, it should be split
  - Does it have lessons that don't belong in this chapter? If so, they should be removed
